feed.title: Goldfish: Spoofing wallet fingerprints to improve privacy

entry.title: Goldfish: Spoofing wallet fingerprints to improve privacy
entry.summary: In this email, the sender discusses the problem of wallet fingerprinting in Bitcoin transactions. They provide a summary of previous research on this topic, including a blog post by 0xB10C in 2020 and a tool created by achow101 in 2022. The suggested solutions to address wallet fingerprinting include introducing randomness in fee rates, broadening the fingerprint by supporting different address types, time-locking transactions to the current block height, and setting a random transaction version.The sender also mentions their own blog post on wallet fingerprinting based on nLocktime and nVersion used by different wallets. Additionally, they refer to a recent blog post by ishaanam which categorizes fingerprints into four types (Independent, Probabilistic, Dependent, and Temporal) and provides observations on eight different Bitcoin wallets.A table displaying the fingerprints and a link to a Wallet Fingerprint Detector are included in the email. The conclusion drawn is that while there is no clear solution to the discussed issues, eliminating fingerprinting entirely would be difficult. The sender suggests that spoofing wallet fingerprints could be a viable solution for users who prioritize privacy.They compare wallet fingerprinting to browser fingerprinting and mention that existing tools attempting to identify wallets from transactions often result in false positives. Introducing spoofing could further increase these false positives, making chain analysis more challenging and enhancing privacy. The sender notes that some privacy-focused wallets may consider implementing this feature.The email ends with acknowledgments to 0xB10C, achow101, ishaanam, pythcoiner, and statusquont, and is sent with Proton Mail secure email.
